               <div class="txtNew" data-packed="false" id="j95tab71" style="top:131px;bottom:;left:19px;right:;width:398px;height:auto;position:absolute">
                <p class="font_9">
                 Martin Clearwater &amp; Bell
                 <span style="font-size:11px;">
                  LLP
                 </span>
                 , which has the distinction of being the oldest and largest medical defense firm in New York, has expanded over recent decades to specialize in all areas of professional liability, medical and healthcare litigation. Our defense practices include medical malpractice, healthcare litigation, employment and labor, toxic tort and product liability, professional liability and appellate matters.
                </p>
                <p class="font_9">
                </p>
                <p class="font_9">
                 Recognized by both the bench and bar as a leader in the medical defense and professional liability areas, MCB has served the professional community for over one hundred years. What truly sets MCB apart from its competition is its depth of talent and stability.  All of the Firm's senior partners have over 20 years of experience or more with the Firm.
                </p>
                <p class="font_9">
                </p>
                <p class="font_9">
                 As a result of our commitment to excellence, MCB has grown steadily over the years from a dozen attorneys, including three partners, in the mid-1970’s to more than 75 attorneys today.  MCB has been honored by The American Lawyer as a Top 100 New York Law Firm and has three senior partners who are Fellows of the American College of Trial Lawyers. In addition, a number of Firm partners are selected by their peers for inclusion in Best Lawyers in America as well as Super Lawyers. Most of the Firm’s partners are AV rated by Martindale-Hubbell, their highest rating.
                </p>
               </div>

McCrory and Yuko A. Nakahara was published in the July 9, 2018 issue of <span style=\"font-style: italic;\">MD News Long Island. <\/span><\/hatul><hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\">With the increased litigation against short- or long-term care facilities and hospitals relative to the care and treatment rendered to elderly patients, there is an associated increase in litigation against physicians specializing in geriatric and palliative care medicine, as well as physicians who provide consultations to this population. So why and how are physicians brought into a lawsuit?<\/hatul><hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\"><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a dataquery=\"#txtMedia1ehr\">Click to read full article. <\/a><\/span><\/span><\/hatul>","links":[{"linkId":"txtMedia1w84","_type":"wix:ExternalLink","target":"_blank","protocol":"http","address":"longisland.mdnews.com\/actions-against-physicians-involving-geriatric-and-palliative-medicine"},{"linkId":"txtMedia1ehr","_type":"wix:ExternalLink","target":"_blank","protocol":"http","address":"longisland.mdnews.com\/actions-against-physicians-involving-geriatric-and-palliative-medicine"}],"version":3},"coverImageData":{"_type":"CoverImageData","coverImageType":"","video":{"_type":"wix:Video","videoId":"","videoType":"","thumbnail":""},"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"","width":1280,"height":960},"isHD":false,"isHeroImage":false},"description":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"","links":[],"version":1},"mobileTitle":"MD News Article: Actions Against Physicians Involving Geriatric and Palliative Medicine","_iid":"5b51ee76e6ac71759bd5fc7b","_hash":"c4d19d33c5673e4501993d9448d23cf1","_createdAt":"2018-07-20T14:15:18.508Z","_updatedAt":"2018-07-20T14:16:45.491Z","permalink":"2018\/07\/20\/MD-News-Article-Actions-Against-Physicians-Involving-Geriatric-and-Palliative-Medicine","permalinkVersion":"2","defaultPost":false,"author":"","categories":[]},"5b48e31fe6ac713789932592":{"_type":"MediaPost","title":"MCB Motion for Summary Judgment Victory in Dental Malpractice Case","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2018-07-13T17:36:38.548Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"<hatul >Senior Partner Jeffrey Shor and Associate Kevin Marks successfully moved for summary judgment before Honorable Justice Joan A. Madden in the New York County Supreme Court in a case alleging failure to timely diagnose and treat a benign but aggressive neoplasm of the right mandible. Plaintiff argued that our client dental office failed to appreciate a neoplastic lesion on plaintiff’s radiographs for the period of one year, delaying her diagnosis and resulting in a partial mandibulectomy and reconstruction with loss of teeth, nerve damage, and permanent difficulty speaking and eating. In MCB’s motion, written by Kevin Marks, we were able to establish through our oral and maxillofacial surgery expert that plaintiff’s condition already required a significantly similar resection and reconstruction procedure prior to the alleged delay. The Court agreed with MCB’s argument that plaintiff had failed to submit any evidence that the neoplasm had grown during that year so as to require a more expansive resection procedure or that any specific injury could have prevented by an earlier surgery. Accordingly, the Court found that our client dental office’s alleged delay was not a proximate cause of plaintiff’s injuries, and the matter was dismissed with prejudice.<\/hatul>","links":[],"version":3},"coverImageData":{"_type":"CoverImageData","coverImageType":"","video":{"_type":"wix:Video","videoId":"","videoType":"","thumbnail":""},"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"","width":1280,"height":960},"isHD":false,"isHeroImage":false},"description":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"","links":[],"version":1},"mobileTitle":"MCB Motion for Summary Judgment Victory in Dental Malpractice Case","_iid":"5b48e31fe6ac713789932592","_hash":"a190666a51f7f6669699c45372d8dc42","_createdAt":"2018-07-13T17:36:31.464Z","_updatedAt":"2018-07-13T17:36:39.669Z","permalink":"2018\/07\/13\/MCB-Motion-for-Summary-Judgment-Victory-in-Dental-Malpractice-Case","permalinkVersion":"2","defaultPost":false,"author":"","categories":[]},"5b439cd69890cc1e3460a10c":{"_type":"MediaPost","title":"Defense Verdict Victory in Failure to Diagnose Breast Cancer Case","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2018-07-11T16:17:00.000Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"<hatul  style=\"text-align: justify;\">In June 2018, Senior Trial Partner Anthony M. Sola, assisted by Partner Thomas Kroczynski, Associate Kerona Samuels and paralegal Marilyn Weiss&nbsp;obtained a defense verdict after a 2 week trial in Supreme Court, Queens County before Justice Earnest Hart.<\/hatul><hatul  style=\"text-align: justify;\">The case involved a claimed&nbsp;failure to diagnose breast cancer in a then 42 year old married, working mother of 3 children.&nbsp; We represented the only defendant, a radiologist, and it was claimed she misread a mammogram on October 31, 2013. Seventeen months later the plaintiff&nbsp;was diagnosed with an invasive lobular breast cancer at Sage IIIC with a significantly shortened life expectancy. At the time of diagnosis the tumor was approximately 8 x 8 x 5 cms. in size, and had spread to 10 of 18 lymph nodes. She had undergone bilateral mastectomies, breast reconstruction, chemo therapy &amp; radiation therapy.<\/hatul><hatul  style=\"text-align: justify;\">Our defense was that her lobular breast cancer was a very aggressive, inflammatory cancer with an exceptionally fast doubling time. As such, if one used a fast doubling time for the tumor and calculated going back in time, the tumor at the time&nbsp;of our client’s October 2013 mammogram would have been so small as to not have been detectable, especially since she had dense breast tissue which makes detecting a lobular breast cancer on mammography&nbsp;difficult under any circumstances.&nbsp;<\/hatul><hatul  style=\"text-align: justify;\">Of course, plaintiff had expert witnesses&nbsp;in radiology and medical oncology who testified, contrary to our position,&nbsp;that the tumor doubled&nbsp;in volume only at an average rate of every 90 days&nbsp;and therefore&nbsp;was 2.5 cm in size and very detectable in October 2013.&nbsp; Consequently, we had - as usual - a clear cut credibility issue between the plaintiff and the defense cases.&nbsp;&nbsp;<\/hatul><hatul  style=\"text-align: justify;\">Here is where our work-up on the experts proved extremely helpful.&nbsp;&nbsp; Ms. Samuels did an excellent job digesting scores of transcripts of the plaintiffs’ experts. On cross examination, as one example, plaintiff’s oncologist denied that inflammatory breast cancer has a doubling time of only 30 days. But we had a transcript from one of his prior cases in which&nbsp;he said exactly that. He also denied on cross that the skin in inflammatory breast cancer has the look of an orange peel;&nbsp; &nbsp;again,&nbsp;he testified contrary to his present testimony in a prior case.&nbsp; Finally, he testified the patient did not have inflammatory&nbsp;breast cancer, but we had the plaintiff’s Memorial Sloane Kettering records which had that as the diagnosis.&nbsp; So by being able to demonstrate that he had given completely different testimony in prior cases under oath, and contradicted a Memorial record, we were able to impeach his credibility.<\/hatul><hatul  style=\"text-align: justify;\">Additionally, plaintiff put on a treating psychologist as a damages witness.&nbsp; MCB Paralegal Marilyn Weiss&nbsp;conducted research on him and found that 16 years ago he had been convicted of fraudulent billing of Medicare in a Federal felony case had spent 6 months in jail in the Otisville Federal Penitentiary. While this did not go directly to the liability issues, it nevertheless hurt the overall&nbsp;credibility of the plaintiff’s entire case. The net result was&nbsp;a unanimous defendant’s verdict.<\/hatul>","links":[],"version":3},"coverImageData":{"_type":"CoverImageData","coverImageType":"","video":{"_type":"wix:Video","videoId":"","videoType":"","thumbnail":""},"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"","width":1280,"height":960},"isHD":false,"isHeroImage":false},"description":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"","links":[],"version":1},"mobileTitle":"Defense Verdict Victory in Failure to Diagnose Breast Cancer Case","defaultPost":false,"permalink":"2018\/07\/09\/Defense-Verdict-Victory-in-Failure-to-Diagnose-Breast-Cancer-Case","permalinkVersion":"2","_iid":"5b439cd69890cc1e3460a10c","_createdAt":"2018-07-09T17:35:18.396Z","_updatedAt":"2018-07-11T16:22:01.588Z","_hash":"ba36fa0749c3e1e6dec2c2b2253647c0","author":"","categories":[]},"5b3140e149fdd97cbb5518f5":{"_type":"MediaPost","title":"MCB featured in New York Magazine: New York’s Leaders in the Law 2018","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2018-07-10T15:18:00.000Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"<hatul  style=\"line-height: 1em; \"><span style=\"\"><span style=\"line-height: 1em;\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a dataquery=\"#txtMedia1ayz\">Martin Clearwater &amp; Bell LLP<\/a><\/span> was <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a dataquery=\"#txtMedia19k\">featured in New York’s Leaders in the Law 2018.<\/a><\/span><\/span><\/span><\/hatul><hatul  style=\"text-align: justify; line-height: 1em; \"><span style=\"\"><span style=\"line-height: 1em;\"><span style=\"font-style: italic;\">Leaders In The Law <\/span>presents New York’s Leading Lawyers, a special section that highlights the achievements of the tri-state area’s exceptional practitioners. New York offers the best of many industries, one of which is its legal community as you’ll see in these pages. Between multimillion-dollar verdicts, custody battles, injury and malpractice matters, and precedent-setting resolutions, the tri-state area’s lawyers continually excel in their pursuit of justice. But finding the right lawyer amid such a vast talent pool can be challenging, which is why we have compiled this directory of New York’s preeminent lawyers. Their areas of practice are as diverse as New Yorkers themselves, but they all share an unwavering dedication to their clients. Whether your needs stem from personal, medical, financial, familial matters or another reason, the lawyers profiled here will help you reach a favorable outcome.<\/span><\/span><\/hatul>","links":[{"linkId":"txtMedia1ayz","_type":"wix:ExternalLink","target":"_blank","protocol":"http","address":"nymag.com\/nymag\/advertorial\/leaders\/2018\/martin-clearwater-bell\/"},{"linkId":"txtMedia19k","_type":"wix:ExternalLink","target":"_blank","protocol":"http","address":"nymag.com\/nymag\/advertorial\/leaders\/2018\/martin-clearwater-bell\/"}],"version":3},"coverImageData":{"_type":"CoverImageData","coverImageType":"","video":{"_type":"wix:Video","videoId":"","videoType":"","thumbnail":""},"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"","width":1280,"height":960},"isHD":false,"isHeroImage":false},"description":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"","links":[],"version":1},"mobileTitle":"MCB featured in New York Magazine: New York’s Leaders in the Law 2018","_iid":"5b3140e149fdd97cbb5518f5","_hash":"a43a0548b8c0bba46d3c81d4dd18e2e5","_createdAt":"2018-06-25T19:22:09.877Z","_updatedAt":"2018-07-10T15:23:01.231Z","defaultPost":false,"permalink":"2018\/07\/10\/MCB-featured-in-New-York-Magazine-Legal-Leaders-for-2018","permalinkVersion":"2","author":"","categories":[]},"5b3a786b3a1a3d4b962ce1f5":{"_type":"MediaPost","title":"MD News Article: The Significant Impact on Treating Patients with Parkinson’s Disease","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2018-07-02T19:31:01.058Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"<hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\">\"The Significant Impact on Treating Patients with Parkinson’s Disease\" by Michael A. Sonkin and Samantha E. Shaw was published in the June 2018 edition of MD News - Long Island. <span style=\"font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a dataquery=\"#txtMediaw5p\">Click here to read.<\/a><\/span><\/span><\/hatul><hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\">\"Parkinson’s disease is a progressive disorder of the nervous system that affects movements. There are well-recognized signs and symptoms of Parkinson’s disease, including both motor and nonmotor symptoms. Some of the most common symptoms include tremors, slowed movement, rigidity, postural instability, cognitive impairment, mood disorders, sleeping issues, low blood pressure, constipation, and difficulties with speech, swallowing and writing. The symptoms vary from patient to patient as does the overall progression and severity of the disease. As discussed in more detail below, treating patients with Parkinson’s disease is often complex, and can give rise to situations that increase the likelihood of a lawsuit. Specifically, patients with Parkinson’s disease are both inherently more susceptible to injury and can experience hindered recoveries as a result of the disease.\"<br>\n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><\/span><\/span><br>\n<\/hatul><hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\"><a dataquery=\"#txtMedia1ilx\"><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">Click here to read the full article.<\/span><\/span><\/a><\/hatul>","links":[{"linkId":"txtMediaw5p","_type":"wix:ExternalLink","target":"_blank","protocol":"http","address":"longisland.mdnews.com\/significant-impact-treating-patients-parkinson%E2%80%99s-disease"},{"linkId":"txtMedia1ilx","_type":"wix:ExternalLink","target":"_blank","protocol":"http","address":"longisland.mdnews.com\/significant-impact-treating-patients-parkinson%E2%80%99s-disease"}],"version":3},"coverImageData":{"_type":"CoverImageData","coverImageType":"","video":{"_type":"wix:Video","videoId":"","videoType":"","thumbnail":""},"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"","width":1280,"height":960},"isHD":false,"isHeroImage":false},"description":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"","links":[],"version":1},"mobileTitle":"MD Disease","defaultPost":false,"permalink":"2018\/07\/02\/MD-News-Article-The-Significant-Impact-on-Treating-Patients-with-Parkinson%E2%80%99s-Disease","permalinkVersion":"2","_iid":"5b3a786b3a1a3d4b962ce1f5","_createdAt":"2018-07-02T19:09:31.044Z","_updatedAt":"2018-07-02T19:31:01.864Z","_hash":"74b9767f1ec7554892ba734f4b01feec","author":"","categories":[]},"5b313e8c3a1a3d2b529a85a1":{"_type":"MediaPost","title":"Senior Partner Kenneth Larywon presents at World Ophthalmology Conference in Barcelona","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2018-06-25T19:19:38.710Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"<hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\">Senior Partner Kenneth Larywon was invited to speak in the International Council of Opthalmology's <span style=\"font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a dataquery=\"#txtMedia17v5\">World Ophthalmology Conference for 2018<\/a><\/span><a dataquery=\"#txtMedia17v5\"> <\/a><\/span>in Barcelona, Spain.<\/hatul><hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\"><br>\nMr. Larywon discussed&nbsp;medical malpractice laws in the United States in a program&nbsp;entitled \"Defending the Ophthalmologist in a Medical Malpractice Lawsuit: Global Comparative Overview of Multiple Legal Systems.\" Mr. Larywon was joined by several renowned&nbsp;speakers who discussed&nbsp;medical malpractice in their respective countries including Dr. Sunil Moreker of India, Dr. Kenji Minemura of Japan&nbsp;and&nbsp;attorneys Ignacio Montoro Iturbe-Ormaeche, Esq. and &nbsp;Juan Manuel Quintana Zuazúa, Esq. of Spain. The program was chaired by&nbsp;&nbsp;Robert Ritch, MD.<\/hatul>","links":[{"linkId":"txtMedia17v5","_type":"wix:ExternalLink","target":"_blank","protocol":"https","address":"www.wocabstracts.org\/index.cfm?do=ev.pubEventGridByTime&style=0&showByDay=all"},{"linkId":"txtMedia17v5","_type":"wix:ExternalLink","target":"_blank","protocol":"https","address":"www.wocabstracts.org\/index.cfm?do=ev.pubEventGridByTime&style=0&showByDay=all"}],"version":3},"coverImageData":{"_type":"CoverImageData","coverImageType":"","video":{"_type":"wix:Video","videoId":"","videoType":"","thumbnail":""},"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"","width":1280,"height":960},"isHD":false,"isHeroImage":false},"description":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"","links":[],"version":1},"mobileTitle":"Senior Partner Kenneth Larywon presents at World Ophthalmology Conference in Barcelona","_iid":"5b313e8c3a1a3d2b529a85a1","_hash":"74bf709b3a439eed4dfb07b40ddeca8c","_createdAt":"2018-06-25T19:12:12.928Z","_updatedAt":"2018-06-25T19:20:21.449Z","permalink":"2018\/06\/25\/Senior-Partner-Kenneth-Larywon-presents-at-World-Ophthalmology-Conference-in-Barcelona","permalinkVersion":"2","defaultPost":false,"author":"","categories":[]},"5b1a7f716f8a3e3b694e9ea7":{"_type":"MediaPost","title":"Defense Verdict Obtained By Anthony Sola in Failure to Diagnose DLBCL","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2018-06-08T13:07:35.125Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"<hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\">May 2018: Senior Trial Partner Anthony M. Sola, assisted by Of Counsel Tracy A. Abramson and Associate Jacqueline A. Wild,&nbsp; obtained a defense verdict after a 3 week trial in Supreme Court, Nassau County before Justice Thomas&nbsp; Feinman.&nbsp;&nbsp; The case involved an allegation that the defendant physicians failed to diagnose a Diffuse Large B Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL) in the lung&nbsp; of a 29 year old woman during her pregnancy. During her entire pregnancy she&nbsp;&nbsp; complained of&nbsp; a severe cough&nbsp; and chest pain, and,&nbsp; starting in the second trimester,&nbsp; she developed a severe rash over most of her body.&nbsp; A month after her delivery, her family doctor ordered a chest x-ray which soon after led to a diagnosis of a Stage IV DLBCL for which she was treated at Memorial Sloan Kettering Medical Center with an experimental therapy protocol. She was still in remission at the time of trial. In retrospect, the cough, chest pain and rash were due to the DLBCL.<br>\n<br>\nAt trial, the defense focused on the fact that the plaintiff’s complaints were outside of their area of expertise so they&nbsp; properly referred the patient to a pulmonary specialist and a dermatologist who were not named defendants. Plaintiff claimed that the obstetricians were acting as her primary care doctor during the pregnancy and failed to coordinate the care and arrange, among other things,&nbsp; for&nbsp; a chest imaging study suggested by one of the pulmonologists. We were able to impeach the credibility of the plaintiff on the issue of who was her primary care physician by introducing a record we uncovered during our&nbsp; pretrial preparation that showed the plaintiff went to a different doctor during her pregnancy at which time she wrote on that doctor’s intake form the name of&nbsp; a another&nbsp; doctor as her primary&nbsp; care physician. We further were able to demonstrate that the suggestion for&nbsp; a chest imaging study was one that the outside specialist was considering performing and was not a recommendation to the obstetricians to order. Finally, we were able to prove that the patient herself failed to follow up with some of&nbsp; the outside specialists.<br>\n<br>\nThe jury returned a verdict in favor of the defendants dismissing the entire complaint.&nbsp; Because the jury did not completely follow the instructions on the&nbsp; verdict sheet, they went further than required and also answered the culpable conduct questions, finding that the plaintiff herself was 100% responsible for any delay in the diagnosis!<br>\n<br>\n&nbsp;<\/hatul>","links":[],"version":3},"coverImageData":{"_type":"CoverImageData","coverImageType":"","video":{"_type":"wix:Video","videoId":"","videoType":"","thumbnail":""},"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"","width":1280,"height":960},"isHD":false,"isHeroImage":false},"description":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"","links":[],"version":1},"mobileTitle":"Defense Verdict Obtained By Anthony Sola in Failure to Diagnose DLBCL","_iid":"5b1a7f716f8a3e3b694e9ea7","_hash":"bca9cc6320937d277a43bf3c91e7fdd3","_createdAt":"2018-06-08T13:06:57.645Z","_updatedAt":"2018-06-08T13:07:35.708Z","permalink":"2018\/06\/08\/Defense-Verdict-Obtained-By-Anthony-Sola-in-Failure-to-Diagnose-DLBCL","permalinkVersion":"2","defaultPost":false,"author":"","categories":[]},"5b197b82e6ac710f45483bfd":{"_type":"MediaPost","title":"MD News Article: How Effective Informed Consent Practices Support the Defense of the Surgical Complication at Trial","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2018-06-07T18:39:42.759Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"<hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\"><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><\/span><\/span><br>\n<\/hatul><hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\"><a dataquery=\"#txtMedia23pf\"><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">\"How Effective Informed Consent Practices Support the Defense of the Surgical Complication at Trial\"<\/span>&nbsp; <\/span>by Anthony M. Sola and Daniel L. Freidlin was published in the May 2018 edition of MD News Long Island. <\/a><\/hatul><hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\">\"Hysterectomy is one of the most frequently performed gynecologic operations worldwide. As with any pelvic surgery, it may be complicated by injury to surrounding organs, such as bowel, bladder or ureters. Retrospective studies have found that the risk of such damage is approximately one to two percent. As the average gynecologist performs hundreds of hysterectomies over the course of a career, such a complication is likely to be encountered at some point. When the injury results in incontinence, a lawsuit often follows.\"<\/hatul><hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a dataquery=\"#txtMediaciw\"><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Read the full article here.<\/span><\/a><\/span><\/hatul>","links":[{"linkId":"txtMedia23pf","_type":"wix:ExternalLink","target":"_blank","protocol":"http","address":"longisland.mdnews.com\/how-effective-informed-consent-practices-support-defense-surgical-complication-trial"},{"linkId":"txtMediaciw","_type":"wix:ExternalLink","target":"_blank","protocol":"http","address":"longisland.mdnews.com\/how-effective-informed-consent-practices-support-defense-surgical-complication-trial"}],"version":3},"coverImageData":{"_type":"CoverImageData","coverImageType":"","video":{"_type":"wix:Video","videoId":"","videoType":"","thumbnail":""},"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"","width":1280,"height":960},"isHD":false,"isHeroImage":false},"description":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"","links":[],"version":1},"mobileTitle":"MD News Article: How Effective Informed Consent Practices Support the Defense of the Surgical Complication at Trial","_iid":"5b197b82e6ac710f45483bfd","_hash":"a5098cd4685201e9b24302b869383771","_createdAt":"2018-06-07T18:37:54.827Z","_updatedAt":"2018-06-07T18:40:19.410Z","permalink":"2018\/06\/07\/MD-News-Article-How-Effective-Informed-Consent-Practices-Support-the-Defense-of-the-Surgical-Complication-at-Trial","permalinkVersion":"2","defaultPost":false,"author":"","categories":[]}},"converted":{"Posts":{"5b51ee76e6ac71759bd5fc7b":{"_type":"TextPost","title":"MD News Article: Actions Against Physicians Involving Geriatric and Palliative Medicine","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2018-07-20T14:16:44.729Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"<hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\">\"<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a dataquery=\"#txtMedia1w84\"><span style=\"\">Actions Against Physicians Involving Geriatric and Palliative Medicine<\/span><\/a><\/span><\/span>\" by Partners Rosaleen T. McCrory and Yuko A. Nakahara was published in the July 9, 2018 issue of <span style=\"font-style: italic;\">MD News Long Island. <\/span><\/hatul><hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\">With the increased litigation against short- or long-term care facilities and hospitals relative to the care and treatment rendered to elderly patients, there is an associated increase in litigation against physicians specializing in geriatric and palliative care medicine, as well as physicians who provide consultations to this population. So why and how are physicians brought into a lawsuit?<\/hatul><hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\"><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a dataquery=\"#txtMedia1ehr\">Click to read full article. <\/a><\/span><\/span><\/hatul>","links":[{"linkId":"txtMedia1w84","_type":"wix:ExternalLink","target":"_blank","protocol":"http","address":"longisland.mdnews.com\/actions-against-physicians-involving-geriatric-and-palliative-medicine"},{"linkId":"txtMedia1ehr","_type":"wix:ExternalLink","target":"_blank","protocol":"http","address":"longisland.mdnews.com\/actions-against-physicians-involving-geriatric-and-palliative-medicine"}],"version":3},"coverImageData":{"_type":"CoverImageData","coverImageType":"","video":{"_type":"wix:Video","videoId":"","videoType":"","thumbnail":""},"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"","width":1280,"height":960},"isHD":false,"isHeroImage":false},"description":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"","links":[],"version":1},"mobileTitle":"MD News Article: Actions Against Physicians Involving Geriatric and Palliative Medicine","_iid":"5b51ee76e6ac71759bd5fc7b","_hash":"c4d19d33c5673e4501993d9448d23cf1","_createdAt":"2018-07-20T14:15:18.508Z","_updatedAt":"2018-07-20T14:16:45.491Z","permalink":"2018\/07\/20\/MD-News-Article-Actions-Against-Physicians-Involving-Geriatric-and-Palliative-Medicine","permalinkVersion":"2","defaultPost":false,"author":"","categories":[],"httpsOnPublish":false},"5b48e31fe6ac713789932592":{"_type":"TextPost","title":"MCB Motion for Summary Judgment Victory in Dental Malpractice Case","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2018-07-13T17:36:38.548Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"<hatul >Senior Partner Jeffrey Shor and Associate Kevin Marks successfully moved for summary judgment before Honorable Justice Joan A. Madden in the New York County Supreme Court in a case alleging failure to timely diagnose and treat a benign but aggressive neoplasm of the right mandible. Plaintiff argued that our client dental office failed to appreciate a neoplastic lesion on plaintiff’s radiographs for the period of one year, delaying her diagnosis and resulting in a partial mandibulectomy and reconstruction with loss of teeth, nerve damage, and permanent difficulty speaking and eating. In MCB’s motion, written by Kevin Marks, we were able to establish through our oral and maxillofacial surgery expert that plaintiff’s condition already required a significantly similar resection and reconstruction procedure prior to the alleged delay. The Court agreed with MCB’s argument that plaintiff had failed to submit any evidence that the neoplasm had grown during that year so as to require a more expansive resection procedure or that any specific injury could have prevented by an earlier surgery. Accordingly, the Court found that our client dental office’s alleged delay was not a proximate cause of plaintiff’s injuries, and the matter was dismissed with prejudice.<\/hatul>","links":[],"version":3},"coverImageData":{"_type":"CoverImageData","coverImageType":"","video":{"_type":"wix:Video","videoId":"","videoType":"","thumbnail":""},"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"","width":1280,"height":960},"isHD":false,"isHeroImage":false},"description":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"","links":[],"version":1},"mobileTitle":"MCB Motion for Summary Judgment Victory in Dental Malpractice Case","_iid":"5b48e31fe6ac713789932592","_hash":"a190666a51f7f6669699c45372d8dc42","_createdAt":"2018-07-13T17:36:31.464Z","_updatedAt":"2018-07-13T17:36:39.669Z","permalink":"2018\/07\/13\/MCB-Motion-for-Summary-Judgment-Victory-in-Dental-Malpractice-Case","permalinkVersion":"2","defaultPost":false,"author":"","categories":[],"httpsOnPublish":false},"5b439cd69890cc1e3460a10c":{"_type":"TextPost","title":"Defense Verdict Victory in Failure to Diagnose Breast Cancer Case","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2018-07-11T16:17:00.000Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"<hatul  style=\"text-align: justify;\">In June 2018, Senior Trial Partner Anthony M. Sola, assisted by Partner Thomas Kroczynski, Associate Kerona Samuels and paralegal Marilyn Weiss&nbsp;obtained a defense verdict after a 2 week trial in Supreme Court, Queens County before Justice Earnest Hart.<\/hatul><hatul  style=\"text-align: justify;\">The case involved a claimed&nbsp;failure to diagnose breast cancer in a then 42 year old married, working mother of 3 children.&nbsp; We represented the only defendant, a radiologist, and it was claimed she misread a mammogram on October 31, 2013. Seventeen months later the plaintiff&nbsp;was diagnosed with an invasive lobular breast cancer at Sage IIIC with a significantly shortened life expectancy. At the time of diagnosis the tumor was approximately 8 x 8 x 5 cms. in size, and had spread to 10 of 18 lymph nodes. She had undergone bilateral mastectomies, breast reconstruction, chemo therapy &amp; radiation therapy.<\/hatul><hatul  style=\"text-align: justify;\">Our defense was that her lobular breast cancer was a very aggressive, inflammatory cancer with an exceptionally fast doubling time. As such, if one used a fast doubling time for the tumor and calculated going back in time, the tumor at the time&nbsp;of our client’s October 2013 mammogram would have been so small as to not have been detectable, especially since she had dense breast tissue which makes detecting a lobular breast cancer on mammography&nbsp;difficult under any circumstances.&nbsp;<\/hatul><hatul  style=\"text-align: justify;\">Of course, plaintiff had expert witnesses&nbsp;in radiology and medical oncology who testified, contrary to our position,&nbsp;that the tumor doubled&nbsp;in volume only at an average rate of every 90 days&nbsp;and therefore&nbsp;was 2.5 cm in size and very detectable in October 2013.&nbsp; Consequently, we had - as usual - a clear cut credibility issue between the plaintiff and the defense cases.&nbsp;&nbsp;<\/hatul><hatul  style=\"text-align: justify;\">Here is where our work-up on the experts proved extremely helpful.&nbsp;&nbsp; Ms. Samuels did an excellent job digesting scores of transcripts of the plaintiffs’ experts. On cross examination, as one example, plaintiff’s oncologist denied that inflammatory breast cancer has a doubling time of only 30 days. But we had a transcript from one of his prior cases in which&nbsp;he said exactly that. He also denied on cross that the skin in inflammatory breast cancer has the look of an orange peel;&nbsp; &nbsp;again,&nbsp;he testified contrary to his present testimony in a prior case.&nbsp; Finally, he testified the patient did not have inflammatory&nbsp;breast cancer, but we had the plaintiff’s Memorial Sloane Kettering records which had that as the diagnosis.&nbsp; So by being able to demonstrate that he had given completely different testimony in prior cases under oath, and contradicted a Memorial record, we were able to impeach his credibility.<\/hatul><hatul  style=\"text-align: justify;\">Additionally, plaintiff put on a treating psychologist as a damages witness.&nbsp; MCB Paralegal Marilyn Weiss&nbsp;conducted research on him and found that 16 years ago he had been convicted of fraudulent billing of Medicare in a Federal felony case had spent 6 months in jail in the Otisville Federal Penitentiary. While this did not go directly to the liability issues, it nevertheless hurt the overall&nbsp;credibility of the plaintiff’s entire case. The net result was&nbsp;a unanimous defendant’s verdict.<\/hatul>","links":[],"version":3},"coverImageData":{"_type":"CoverImageData","coverImageType":"","video":{"_type":"wix:Video","videoId":"","videoType":"","thumbnail":""},"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"","width":1280,"height":960},"isHD":false,"isHeroImage":false},"description":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"","links":[],"version":1},"mobileTitle":"Defense Verdict Victory in Failure to Diagnose Breast Cancer Case","defaultPost":false,"permalink":"2018\/07\/09\/Defense-Verdict-Victory-in-Failure-to-Diagnose-Breast-Cancer-Case","permalinkVersion":"2","_iid":"5b439cd69890cc1e3460a10c","_createdAt":"2018-07-09T17:35:18.396Z","_updatedAt":"2018-07-11T16:22:01.588Z","_hash":"ba36fa0749c3e1e6dec2c2b2253647c0","author":"","categories":[],"httpsOnPublish":false},"5b3140e149fdd97cbb5518f5":{"_type":"TextPost","title":"MCB featured in New York Magazine: New York’s Leaders in the Law 2018","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2018-07-10T15:18:00.000Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"<hatul  style=\"line-height: 1em; \"><span style=\"\"><span style=\"line-height: 1em;\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a dataquery=\"#txtMedia1ayz\">Martin Clearwater &amp; Bell LLP<\/a><\/span> was <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a dataquery=\"#txtMedia19k\">featured in New York’s Leaders in the Law 2018.<\/a><\/span><\/span><\/span><\/hatul><hatul  style=\"text-align: justify; line-height: 1em; \"><span style=\"\"><span style=\"line-height: 1em;\"><span style=\"font-style: italic;\">Leaders In The Law <\/span>presents New York’s Leading Lawyers, a special section that highlights the achievements of the tri-state area’s exceptional practitioners. New York offers the best of many industries, one of which is its legal community as you’ll see in these pages. Between multimillion-dollar verdicts, custody battles, injury and malpractice matters, and precedent-setting resolutions, the tri-state area’s lawyers continually excel in their pursuit of justice. But finding the right lawyer amid such a vast talent pool can be challenging, which is why we have compiled this directory of New York’s preeminent lawyers. Their areas of practice are as diverse as New Yorkers themselves, but they all share an unwavering dedication to their clients. Whether your needs stem from personal, medical, financial, familial matters or another reason, the lawyers profiled here will help you reach a favorable outcome.<\/span><\/span><\/hatul>","links":[{"linkId":"txtMedia1ayz","_type":"wix:ExternalLink","target":"_blank","protocol":"http","address":"nymag.com\/nymag\/advertorial\/leaders\/2018\/martin-clearwater-bell\/"},{"linkId":"txtMedia19k","_type":"wix:ExternalLink","target":"_blank","protocol":"http","address":"nymag.com\/nymag\/advertorial\/leaders\/2018\/martin-clearwater-bell\/"}],"version":3},"coverImageData":{"_type":"CoverImageData","coverImageType":"","video":{"_type":"wix:Video","videoId":"","videoType":"","thumbnail":""},"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"","width":1280,"height":960},"isHD":false,"isHeroImage":false},"description":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"","links":[],"version":1},"mobileTitle":"MCB featured in New York Magazine: New York’s Leaders in the Law 2018","_iid":"5b3140e149fdd97cbb5518f5","_hash":"a43a0548b8c0bba46d3c81d4dd18e2e5","_createdAt":"2018-06-25T19:22:09.877Z","_updatedAt":"2018-07-10T15:23:01.231Z","defaultPost":false,"permalink":"2018\/07\/10\/MCB-featured-in-New-York-Magazine-Legal-Leaders-for-2018","permalinkVersion":"2","author":"","categories":[],"httpsOnPublish":false},"5b3a786b3a1a3d4b962ce1f5":{"_type":"TextPost","title":"MD News Article: The Significant Impact on Treating Patients with Parkinson’s Disease","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2018-07-02T19:31:01.058Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"<hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\">\"The Significant Impact on Treating Patients with Parkinson’s Disease\" by Michael A. Sonkin and Samantha E. Shaw was published in the June 2018 edition of MD News - Long Island. <span style=\"font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a dataquery=\"#txtMediaw5p\">Click here to read.<\/a><\/span><\/span><\/hatul><hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\">\"Parkinson’s disease is a progressive disorder of the nervous system that affects movements. There are well-recognized signs and symptoms of Parkinson’s disease, including both motor and nonmotor symptoms. Some of the most common symptoms include tremors, slowed movement, rigidity, postural instability, cognitive impairment, mood disorders, sleeping issues, low blood pressure, constipation, and difficulties with speech, swallowing and writing. The symptoms vary from patient to patient as does the overall progression and severity of the disease. As discussed in more detail below, treating patients with Parkinson’s disease is often complex, and can give rise to situations that increase the likelihood of a lawsuit. Specifically, patients with Parkinson’s disease are both inherently more susceptible to injury and can experience hindered recoveries as a result of the disease.\"<br>\n<span style=\"font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><\/span><\/span><br>\n<\/hatul><hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\"><a dataquery=\"#txtMedia1ilx\"><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">Click here to read the full article.<\/span><\/span><\/a><\/hatul>","links":[{"linkId":"txtMediaw5p","_type":"wix:ExternalLink","target":"_blank","protocol":"http","address":"longisland.mdnews.com\/significant-impact-treating-patients-parkinson%E2%80%99s-disease"},{"linkId":"txtMedia1ilx","_type":"wix:ExternalLink","target":"_blank","protocol":"http","address":"longisland.mdnews.com\/significant-impact-treating-patients-parkinson%E2%80%99s-disease"}],"version":3},"coverImageData":{"_type":"CoverImageData","coverImageType":"","video":{"_type":"wix:Video","videoId":"","videoType":"","thumbnail":""},"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"","width":1280,"height":960},"isHD":false,"isHeroImage":false},"description":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"","links":[],"version":1},"mobileTitle":"MD News Article: The Significant Impact on Treating Patients with Parkinson’s Disease","defaultPost":false,"permalink":"2018\/07\/02\/MD-News-Article-The-Significant-Impact-on-Treating-Patients-with-Parkinson%E2%80%99s-Disease","permalinkVersion":"2","_iid":"5b3a786b3a1a3d4b962ce1f5","_createdAt":"2018-07-02T19:09:31.044Z","_updatedAt":"2018-07-02T19:31:01.864Z","_hash":"74b9767f1ec7554892ba734f4b01feec","author":"","categories":[],"httpsOnPublish":false},"5b313e8c3a1a3d2b529a85a1":{"_type":"TextPost","title":"Senior Partner Kenneth Larywon presents at World Ophthalmology Conference in Barcelona","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2018-06-25T19:19:38.710Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"<hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\">Senior Partner Kenneth Larywon was invited to speak in the International Council of Opthalmology's <span style=\"font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a dataquery=\"#txtMedia17v5\">World Ophthalmology Conference for 2018<\/a><\/span><a dataquery=\"#txtMedia17v5\"> <\/a><\/span>in Barcelona, Spain.<\/hatul><hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\"><br>\nMr. Larywon discussed&nbsp;medical malpractice laws in the United States in a program&nbsp;entitled \"Defending the Ophthalmologist in a Medical Malpractice Lawsuit: Global Comparative Overview of Multiple Legal Systems.\" Mr. Larywon was joined by several renowned&nbsp;speakers who discussed&nbsp;medical malpractice in their respective countries including Dr. Sunil Moreker of India, Dr. Kenji Minemura of Japan&nbsp;and&nbsp;attorneys Ignacio Montoro Iturbe-Ormaeche, Esq. and &nbsp;Juan Manuel Quintana Zuazúa, Esq. of Spain. The program was chaired by&nbsp;&nbsp;Robert Ritch, MD.<\/hatul>","links":[{"linkId":"txtMedia17v5","_type":"wix:ExternalLink","target":"_blank","protocol":"https","address":"www.wocabstracts.org\/index.cfm?do=ev.pubEventGridByTime&style=0&showByDay=all"},{"linkId":"txtMedia17v5","_type":"wix:ExternalLink","target":"_blank","protocol":"https","address":"www.wocabstracts.org\/index.cfm?do=ev.pubEventGridByTime&style=0&showByDay=all"}],"version":3},"coverImageData":{"_type":"CoverImageData","coverImageType":"","video":{"_type":"wix:Video","videoId":"","videoType":"","thumbnail":""},"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"","width":1280,"height":960},"isHD":false,"isHeroImage":false},"description":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"","links":[],"version":1},"mobileTitle":"Senior Partner Kenneth Larywon presents at World Ophthalmology Conference in Barcelona","_iid":"5b313e8c3a1a3d2b529a85a1","_hash":"74bf709b3a439eed4dfb07b40ddeca8c","_createdAt":"2018-06-25T19:12:12.928Z","_updatedAt":"2018-06-25T19:20:21.449Z","permalink":"2018\/06\/25\/Senior-Partner-Kenneth-Larywon-presents-at-World-Ophthalmology-Conference-in-Barcelona","permalinkVersion":"2","defaultPost":false,"author":"","categories":[],"httpsOnPublish":false},"5b1a7f716f8a3e3b694e9ea7":{"_type":"TextPost","title":"Defense Verdict Obtained By Anthony Sola in Failure to Diagnose DLBCL","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2018-06-08T13:07:35.125Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"<hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\">May 2018: Senior Trial Partner Anthony M. Sola, assisted by Of Counsel Tracy A. Abramson and Associate Jacqueline A. Wild,&nbsp; obtained a defense verdict after a 3 week trial in Supreme Court, Nassau County before Justice Thomas&nbsp; Feinman.&nbsp;&nbsp; The case involved an allegation that the defendant physicians failed to diagnose a Diffuse Large B Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL) in the lung&nbsp; of a 29 year old woman during her pregnancy. During her entire pregnancy she&nbsp;&nbsp; complained of&nbsp; a severe cough&nbsp; and chest pain, and,&nbsp; starting in the second trimester,&nbsp; she developed a severe rash over most of her body.&nbsp; A month after her delivery, her family doctor ordered a chest x-ray which soon after led to a diagnosis of a Stage IV DLBCL for which she was treated at Memorial Sloan Kettering Medical Center with an experimental therapy protocol. She was still in remission at the time of trial. In retrospect, the cough, chest pain and rash were due to the DLBCL.<br>\n<br>\nAt trial, the defense focused on the fact that the plaintiff’s complaints were outside of their area of expertise so they&nbsp; properly referred the patient to a pulmonary specialist and a dermatologist who were not named defendants. Plaintiff claimed that the obstetricians were acting as her primary care doctor during the pregnancy and failed to coordinate the care and arrange, among other things,&nbsp; for&nbsp; a chest imaging study suggested by one of the pulmonologists. We were able to impeach the credibility of the plaintiff on the issue of who was her primary care physician by introducing a record we uncovered during our&nbsp; pretrial preparation that showed the plaintiff went to a different doctor during her pregnancy at which time she wrote on that doctor’s intake form the name of&nbsp; a another&nbsp; doctor as her primary&nbsp; care physician. We further were able to demonstrate that the suggestion for&nbsp; a chest imaging study was one that the outside specialist was considering performing and was not a recommendation to the obstetricians to order. Finally, we were able to prove that the patient herself failed to follow up with some of&nbsp; the outside specialists.<br>\n<br>\nThe jury returned a verdict in favor of the defendants dismissing the entire complaint.&nbsp; Because the jury did not completely follow the instructions on the&nbsp; verdict sheet, they went further than required and also answered the culpable conduct questions, finding that the plaintiff herself was 100% responsible for any delay in the diagnosis!<br>\n<br>\n&nbsp;<\/hatul>","links":[],"version":3},"coverImageData":{"_type":"CoverImageData","coverImageType":"","video":{"_type":"wix:Video","videoId":"","videoType":"","thumbnail":""},"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"","width":1280,"height":960},"isHD":false,"isHeroImage":false},"description":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"","links":[],"version":1},"mobileTitle":"Defense Verdict Obtained By Anthony Sola in Failure to Diagnose DLBCL","_iid":"5b1a7f716f8a3e3b694e9ea7","_hash":"bca9cc6320937d277a43bf3c91e7fdd3","_createdAt":"2018-06-08T13:06:57.645Z","_updatedAt":"2018-06-08T13:07:35.708Z","permalink":"2018\/06\/08\/Defense-Verdict-Obtained-By-Anthony-Sola-in-Failure-to-Diagnose-DLBCL","permalinkVersion":"2","defaultPost":false,"author":"","categories":[],"httpsOnPublish":false},"5b197b82e6ac710f45483bfd":{"_type":"TextPost","title":"MD News Article: How Effective Informed Consent Practices Support the Defense of the Surgical Complication at Trial","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2018-06-07T18:39:42.759Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"<hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\"><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><\/span><\/span><br>\n<\/hatul><hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\"><a dataquery=\"#txtMedia23pf\"><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">\"How Effective Informed Consent Practices Support the Defense of the Surgical Complication at Trial\"<\/span>&nbsp; <\/span>by Anthony M. Sola and Daniel L. Freidlin was published in the May 2018 edition of MD News Long Island. <\/a><\/hatul><hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\">\"Hysterectomy is one of the most frequently performed gynecologic operations worldwide. As with any pelvic surgery, it may be complicated by injury to surrounding organs, such as bowel, bladder or ureters. Retrospective studies have found that the risk of such damage is approximately one to two percent. As the average gynecologist performs hundreds of hysterectomies over the course of a career, such a complication is likely to be encountered at some point. When the injury results in incontinence, a lawsuit often follows.\"<\/hatul><hatul  style=\"line-height: 1.5em;\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a dataquery=\"#txtMediaciw\"><span style=\"font-weight: bold;\">Read the full article here.<\/span><\/a><\/span><\/hatul>","links":[{"linkId":"txtMedia23pf","_type":"wix:ExternalLink","target":"_blank","protocol":"http","address":"longisland.mdnews.com\/how-effective-informed-consent-practices-support-defense-surgical-complication-trial"},{"linkId":"txtMediaciw","_type":"wix:ExternalLink","target":"_blank","protocol":"http","address":"longisland.mdnews.com\/how-effective-informed-consent-practices-support-defense-surgical-complication-trial"}],"version":3},"coverImageData":{"_type":"CoverImageData","coverImageType":"","video":{"_type":"wix:Video","videoId":"","videoType":"","thumbnail":""},"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"","width":1280,"height":960},"isHD":false,"isHeroImage":false},"description":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"","links":[],"version":1},"mobileTitle":"MD
